Package edu.unc.cs.comp524.parsers.prolog

Interface Program

All Known Implementing Classes:
AProgram
public interface Program
A prolog program.

Conceptually, a set of clauses keyed by name (cf. clauses()).

Supports various interrogation methods useful for static source or style checks.

Also provides various static utility methods for processing streams of Relations.

  • Method Details

    • clauses

      Map<String,​List<Relation>> clauses()
      The program's clauses.

      A clause is identified by name; since prolog clauses support overloading by arity, each clause gives a list of possible Relations.

    • arity

      default List<Integer> arity​(String name)
      The arities of all clauses with a given name

    • names

      default List<String> names()
      The names of all clauses

    • relationsWithComments

      default List<Relation> relationsWithComments()
      All Relations that have comments.
      See Also:
      Relation.comment()

    • isRecursive

      default boolean isRecursive​(String name)
      True iff any of the clauses named name directly contains an invocation of itself.
      See Also:
      RuleInvocation.isInvocationOf(edu.unc.cs.comp524.parsers.prolog.Relation), containsRecursive(java.lang.String)

    • containsRecursive

      default boolean containsRecursive​(String name)
      True iff any of the clauses named name contains an invocation to a recurisive clause.
      See Also:
      isRecursive(java.lang.String)

    • undefined

      default List<RuleInvocation> undefined()
      A collection of RuleInvocations of rules not defined anywhere in the program.

      This can be useful when looking at what "standard" library functions were called, or disallowing them altogether.

    • depth

      default int depth​(String name)
      The "depth" of a named clause.

      Implementations are free to define depth in any way.

      The default implementation defines it thusly: the depth is an integer counting how many subrules are invoked until the tree "bottoms out" by invoking a fact with no subrules. Once a subrule is counted as invoked, other invocations of that subrule are ignored (to circumvent infinite loops in the case of recursion, mutual or otherwise) in that particular "path."

      The actual depth is the maximum of all possible depths.

      This is a stand-in measure for things like cyclomatic complexity and maximum runtime-depth, the latter of which cannot be computed statically (cf. Turing's Halting problem).

    • noMagicNumbers

      default boolean noMagicNumbers()
      True iff the program contains no magic numbers

      The default implementation defines that as "no rules have numeric literals that are not 0, 1, or 2; facts are permitted and encouraged to capture needed numeric constants."

    • rules

      static Stream<Rule> rules​(Stream<Relation> relations)
      Only the Rules in the stream of Relations

    • invocations

      static Stream<RuleInvocation> invocations​(Stream<Relation> relations)
      All the RuleInvocations on the right-hand-side of the Rules in the stream of Relations
      See Also:
      Rule.rhs()

    • relations

      default Stream<Relation> relations()
      All the Relations in the program
